 Maximus: Here are your answers.
 
 1) The verse from Matthew is in regards to the end times. At that time all believers will have been raptured off the face of the earth. (This is my reading of scripture and the reading of many Seminary professors I respect. However, there is some argument about the timing of the rapture) The people he is referring to are not already believers. He is speaking to the process of becoming a believer during that dispensation.
 
 2) Adam and Eve never initially received the gift of grace. They were given the choice. The garden had two trees. The tree of the knowledge of good and evil and the tree of life. Notice they did not choose the tree of life (the free gift of grace). You see they were created in unconfirmed righteousness as they had never been tested. At the testing they were confirmed unrighteous. You and I have been RECREATED in confirmed righteousness, that is the righteousness of Jesus Christ. 
 
 3) I do not read the prodigal as Lappster, although I agree with his conclusion, I disagree with his interpretation. Hermaneutically speaking a parable has one point and one point only. Placed in contexts of the remainder of the parables, the lost coin and the lost sheep, the prodigal speaks of the fact that all humans are children of God. That all humans are lost because they, like adam, sinned and would have sinned had they been adam. Adam like the prodigal son asked for his inheritance early. Adam like the prodigal was lost to his father. When the son returned, the father rejoiced. Like rejoicing over the lost coin and the lost sheep. The father looks for us to return. 
 
 4) the unforgivable sin is interesting. 1st the bible teaches that if one can lose their salvation to the unforgivable sin then it also teaches that one can never get it back. Look at the verses that follow that. More likely the conditions that existed at that time (Jesus on Earth at the time and a lack of indwelling of the Holy Spirit) cannot exist at this time and the unforgivable sin cannot be committed by people now.
 
 5) You misquote Peter. It does not say that God wills, It says God wishes. God does not want any to Perish, but we have the choice.
 
 6) As for free will it continues. Free will is free will to act within the designs of your nature. I cannot be a badger, no matter how hard I try. I can only act badger like to a degree because I am not a badger. When God recreates us, He gives us a new nature (I will take their heart of stone and give them a heart of flesh). We now have a nature that is incapable of rejecting our salvation. We still have the free will to act within our nature. We can actually reject God and sin and sin and sin.
